  physical_appearance: There are seven men depicted in this scene. On the left amidst the crowd of four
 is a man in a tailcoat and top hat. He holds in his right hand a parchment
 and a cane on his left. To his left is a moustached man in official robes. Standing to the back of these two men is a man in a colourful turban and Arabic shoes. The men in mandarin garb have long hair queues; in particular
 one man in crimson has his neck chained and is being forcefully being taken away by a man in blue.

  subject_terms_1: arrests (legal events) cultural pluralism officials

  subject_terms_2: China trade painting Parsees Arrest

  subject_terms_3: Painting visual arts

  subject_terms_4: 

  sgcool_label_text: A Parsi merchant
 with his colourful turban
 European man in a tophat
 and Chinese men with long hair queues participate in some as yet unknown activity. The Parsi community was present in Canton by the mid-18th century
 helping to facilitate the British-dominated China trade by importing opium and cotton from India into China
 while exporting tea and silk back to Europe and beyond. By the 19th century
 there was a sizeable community of Europeans.\r\n \r\n

metadata.title_text: Chinese and foreign merchants in Canton
metadata.creator_2: *As mentioned in the stylistic significance field, this work has been attributed to Paqua. NA Paqua
metadata.physical_appearance: There are seven men depicted in this scene. On the left amidst the crowd of four, is a man in a tailcoat and top hat. He holds in his right hand a parchment, and a cane on his left. To his left is a moustached man in official robes. Standing to the back of these two men is a man in a colourful turban and Arabic shoes. The men in mandarin garb have long hair queues; in particular, one man in crimson has his neck chained and is being forcefully being taken away by a man in blue.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: A Parsi merchant, with his colourful turban, European man in a tophat, and Chinese men with long hair queues participate in some as yet unknown activity. The Parsi community was present in Canton by the mid-18th century, helping to facilitate the British-dominated China trade by importing opium and cotton from India into China, while exporting tea and silk back to Europe and beyond. By the 19th century, there was a sizeable community of Europeans.
